ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Provided a good introduction to biophysics for a non-biophysicist. This is a topic that I was broadly interested in and I think that the course covered a lot of ground. I also greatly appreciated the practice at grant writing and enjoyed the practicals on solving protein crystal structures.
Theory behind important biophysical techniques used in research. Through optional meetings in the first half of the class, we learned various experimental and analytical techniques by hand.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The primary strength is that there was a broad range of techniques covered. However, due to this fact a small number of systems could be covered (so that techniques could be compared), which limited the breadth of biophysics covered in the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if a student is interested in biophysics this course is a great introduction to the methods and thought process of approaching biologically relevant problems.
It was a very informative class and very necessary, if you're going to be doing biophysical research.
